description: I would be the first to admit that I love watching college football, and basketball in particular. I am proposing university/college sports, as they now exist in the USA, should be totally eliminated. They have evolved into industries for professional sports in the United States.
text:
I would be the first to admit that I love watching college football, and
basketball in particular. But.

I am proposing university/college sports, as they now exist in the USA, should
be totally eliminated. Try to be calm now and consider this proposal.

Universities are supposed to be centers of learning. They have evolved into
industries for professional sports in the United States. They provide free
minor leagues for MLB, NFL and NBA. In many cases the athletes are "rented" to
colleges for a short time and then go on to professional sports.

Television contracts have escalated to the point of having vast control over
college sports programs to the point that the media owns these programs.
Billions go for college football and basketball, and the other sports are
tolerated and commonly called "Olympic sports" in many cases. The need to
"win" has creating massive scandals and cheating in too many schools.

The amount of money universities in the United States spend on athletics is
staggering, and yet very few are able to actually bring in enough revenue to
cover the vast costs of all of their sports programs . The United States is
the only country in the world with such sports programs based in institutions
of higher learning. But how could our country compete on the world stage if we
eliminate college sports, you say?

To use the Olympics as a comparative, how do other countries manage to win so
many medals? I know, these are minor sports so many of those medals aren't
really important.

Other countries have "clubs" that exist and provide avenues for sports
participation. Many countries fund sports programs, as we do for our National
Olympic organization. MLB does have extensive minor leagues for player
development, but still many players are coming from universities now more than
in the past. Even the NBA now has minor leagues, so why do we need to fund
college basketball to develop their stars for a one-and-done freshman year?
The NFL really has no enduring functional minor league so college football is
it.

Why do so many sports at our University of New Mexico, and of course other
colleges in the United States, have athletic scholarships given to students
from outside the United States? The UNM Golf Team, for example, has many
members who are not U.S. students  why does UNM even have a golf team in the
first place? My tax dollars are supporting UNM in many ways, and it is strange
to support students from other countries who attend college in the United
States to play their sport and get a publicly supported education at the same
time.

Intramural sports can, and do, provide athletic outlets for students who are
interested in exercise and competition.

Again, why do sports programs need to be in universities?

Why should university students be required to pay continually rising athletic
fees to attend school when many of them have no interest in participating,
attending or even watching their college sports teams? This is outrageous and
should be stopped.

Some television networks are so college-sports reliant that they would have a
difficult time staying on the air  sorry ESPN. Others rely on the mega-
billions from advertising for the NFL and the NBA. CBS Sports has basically
created "March Madness." The top echelon of NCAA football is a billion-dollar
enterprise from the playoffs to "The Championship Game."

In fact, the NCAA is all about money and power, and college athletes are just
unpaid participants who actually bring in the dough.

This enormous amount of money has led to massive corruption for universities
that assist or at least allow athletes to be "bribed" to attend prestigious
athletic programs  see Louisville University, University of Kansas and now
allegedly Duke for a few examples.

Make no mistake, this is a huge industry, and I admit it will not go quietly
in the night with all that money at stake.

title: Here's one proposal: Eliminate university sports programs
html:
… I would be the first to admit that I love watching college football, and basketball in particular. But.

I am proposing university/college sports, as they now exist in the USA, should be totally eliminated. Try to be calm now and consider this proposal.

Universities are supposed to be centers of learning. They have evolved into industries for professional sports in the United States. They provide free minor leagues for MLB, NFL and NBA. In many cases the athletes are "rented" to colleges for a short time and then go on to professional sports.

Television contracts have escalated to the point of having vast control over college sports programs to the point that the media owns these programs. Billions go for college football and basketball, and the other sports are tolerated and commonly called "Olympic sports" in many cases. The need to "win" has creating massive scandals and cheating in too many schools.

The amount of money universities in the United States spend on athletics is staggering, and yet very few are able to actually bring in enough revenue to cover the vast costs of all of their sports programs…. The United States is the only country in the world with such sports programs based in institutions of higher learning. But how could our country compete on the world stage if we eliminate college sports, you say?

To use the Olympics as a comparative, how do other countries manage to win so many medals? I know, these are minor sports so many of those medals aren't really important.

Other countries have "clubs" that exist and provide avenues for sports participation. Many countries fund sports programs, as we do for our National Olympic organization. MLB does have extensive minor leagues for player development, but still many players are coming from universities now more than in the past. Even the NBA now has minor leagues, so why do we need to fund college basketball to develop their stars for a one-and-done freshman year? The NFL really has no enduring functional minor league so college football is it.

Why do so many sports at our University of New Mexico, and of course other colleges in the United States, have athletic scholarships given to students from outside the United States? The UNM Golf Team, for example, has many members who are not U.S. students – why does UNM even have a golf team in the first place? My tax dollars are supporting UNM in many ways, and it is strange to support students from other countries who attend college in the United States to play their sport and get a publicly supported education at the same time.

Intramural sports can, and do, provide athletic outlets for students who are interested in exercise and competition.

Again, why do sports programs need to be in universities?

Why should university students be required to pay continually rising athletic fees to attend school when many of them have no interest in participating, attending or even watching their college sports teams? This is outrageous and should be stopped.

Some television networks are so college-sports reliant that they would have a difficult time staying on the air – sorry ESPN. Others rely on the mega-billions from advertising for the NFL and the NBA. CBS Sports has basically created "March Madness." The top echelon of NCAA football is a billion-dollar enterprise from the playoffs to "The Championship Game."

In fact, the NCAA is all about money and power, and college athletes are just unpaid participants who actually bring in the dough.

This enormous amount of money has led to massive corruption for universities that assist or at least allow athletes to be "bribed" to attend prestigious athletic programs – see Louisville University, University of Kansas and now allegedly Duke for a few examples.

Make no mistake, this is a huge industry, and I admit it will not go quietly in the night with all that money at stake.
